title: 110_hr1687
content: The Act may be cited as the "Training for Realtime Writers Act of 2007". Congress finds that the Federal Communications Commission enforces rules for full closed captioning of English television programming since 2006 and will require Spanish captioning by 2010. Over 30 million Americans are deaf or hard of hearing, with 1 in 3 Americans over 60 experiencing hearing loss. Approximately 39 percent of the US population, or 79,000,000 Americans known as "baby boomers," are over 60 years old and have started experiencing hearing loss. Closed captioning is crucial for emergency information in public places, and research shows it helps individuals learning to read English. Authorization of grant program to promote training and job placement of realtime writers. The Secretary of Commerce will provide grants to eligible court reporting programs to train individuals as realtime writers for closed captioning of video programming. Eligible entities must meet educational and financial standards and be accredited by a recognized agency. The Secretary of Commerce will prioritize grants for eligible entities with the most capability to increase training for realtime writers, promising collaborations with local institutions or businesses, and innovative approaches for training or job placement. The grant for realtime writers will last for 2 years and the maximum amount is $1,500,000. SEC. 4. APPLICATION. To apply for a grant under section 3, an eligible entity must submit an application to the Secretary of Commerce with specific information including the training and assistance to be funded, performance measures for evaluating progress, and details on increasing the number of realtime writers. The eligible entity must describe how scholarships will ensure employment as realtime writers, continue training after the grant period, collaborate with local workforce boards, and provide opportunities for disadvantaged or displaced workers. The eligible entity must provide additional information on eligibility for priority grants and any other information required by the Secretary. SEC. 5. USE OF FUNDS. An eligible entity receiving a grant under section 3 must use the funds for recruitment, training, job placement, and assistance of individuals, including those who have completed a court reporting training program. This includes providing scholarships, distance learning, developing English and Spanish curriculum for realtime writing skills, mentoring students, encouraging individuals with disabilities to pursue a career in realtime writing. The scholarship amount for recipients is based on financial need and requires an agreement to provide realtime writing services for a specified period. The Secretary of Commerce oversees coursework and employment related to the scholarship program. The Secretary of Commerce establishes requirements for coursework and employment for scholarship recipients, including repayment conditions. Administrative costs for grants are limited to 5% of the grant amount. Grants under this Act are limited to 5% for administrative costs. The amounts should supplement, not replace, other funds for promoting training and placement of individuals as realtime writers. SEC. 6. REPORTS. Each eligible entity receiving a grant under section 3 must submit an annual report to the Secretary of Commerce detailing the use of grant funds and assessing the effectiveness of activities in increasing the number of realtime writers. The final report must include a description of the best practices. The Inspector General of the Department of Commerce conducts an annual review of grants to assess management and effectiveness. The report includes best practices for increasing the number of trained and employed realtime writers. Authorization of Appropriations: $20,000,000 is authorized for the Secretary of Commerce annually from 2008 to 2012 to implement this Act. Sunset: The Act will be repealed at the end of the fifth fiscal year after funds are allocated.
